rev.comment: None of these non-free images has a rationale for use here, failing [[WP:NFCC]] #10c, and in any case they would not be acceptable use here
rev.diff:
Line 70: Line 70:
===Sliders===
===Sliders===
â
[[File:Sliders - Vortex.jpg|thumb|The Sliders' vortex (ERP bridge).]]
 
In the FOX/Sci-Fi series ''[[Sliders]]'', a method is found to create a wormhole that allows travel not between distant points but between different [[parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universes]]; objects or people that travel through the wormhole begin and end in the same location geographically (e.g. if one leaves San Francisco, one will arrive in an alternate San Francisco) and chronologically (if it is 1999 at the origin point, so it is at the destination, at least by the currently-accepted calendar on our Earth.) Early in the series the wormhole is referred to by the name "Einstein-Rosen-Podolsky bridge," apparently a merging of the concepts of an Einstein-Rosen bridge and the [[EPR paradox|Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen paradox]], a thought-experiment in quantum mechanics. This series presumes that we exist as part of a [[multiverse]] and asks what might have resulted had major or minor events in history occurred differently; the wormholes in the series allow access to the alternate universes in which the series is set. The same premise is used in the ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode ''[[Parallels (TNG episode)|Parallels]]'' and the ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series]]'' episode ''[[The Alternative Factor]]'' which premiered in 1967.
In the FOX/Sci-Fi series ''[[Sliders]]'', a method is found to create a wormhole that allows travel not between distant points but between different [[parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universes]]; objects or people that travel through the wormhole begin and end in the same location geographically (e.g. if one leaves San Francisco, one will arrive in an alternate San Francisco) and chronologically (if it is 1999 at the origin point, so it is at the destination, at least by the currently-accepted calendar on our Earth.) Early in the series the wormhole is referred to by the name "Einstein-Rosen-Podolsky bridge," apparently a merging of the concepts of an Einstein-Rosen bridge and the [[EPR paradox|Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen paradox]], a thought-experiment in quantum mechanics. This series presumes that we exist as part of a [[multiverse]] and asks what might have resulted had major or minor events in history occurred differently; the wormholes in the series allow access to the alternate universes in which the series is set. The same premise is used in the ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode ''[[Parallels (TNG episode)|Parallels]]'' and the ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series]]'' episode ''[[The Alternative Factor]]'' which premiered in 1967.
===Star Wars===
===Star Wars===
â
[[Image:EmperorCliveESB1980.jpg|250px|left|thumb|The Emperor Palpatine]]
 
*The hyperspace travel featured in most of ''Star Wars'' media, is actually a trajectory calculated through wormholes.
*The hyperspace travel featured in most of ''Star Wars'' media, is actually a trajectory calculated through wormholes.
*In ''[[Star Wars: Dark Empire]]'', [[Emperor]] [[Palpatine]] opens Force storms with the form of wormholes, that obliterate an entire Rebel fleet.
*In ''[[Star Wars: Dark Empire]]'', [[Emperor]] [[Palpatine]] opens Force storms with the form of wormholes, that obliterate an entire Rebel fleet.
